statement.text: A golden rectangle is a rectangle whose side lengths are in the golden ratio φ ≈ 1.618. If the width is 1 unit, the height is φ units (or vice versa). The golden rectangle has the unique property that when a square is removed from it, the remaining rectangle is also a golden rectangle.
statement.formal: Let rectangle ABCD have width w and height h. It is a golden rectangle iff h/w = φ = (1+√5)/2

explanation.intuition: Imagine a rectangle that looks 'perfectly balanced'—not too square, not too elongated. The golden rectangle achieves this at the ratio 1:1.618. Its most remarkable feature: if you cut off the largest possible square, what remains is another, smaller golden rectangle. You can repeat this forever, creating an infinite sequence of nested golden rectangles and squares.
explanation.key_insight: The golden rectangle is self-similar: removing a square leaves another golden rectangle. This property generates the golden spiral when you connect the corners of successive squares with quarter-circle arcs. This self-similarity makes it mathematically elegant and appears in optimal packing and growth patterns in nature.
explanation.technical_details: For a golden rectangle with width w, height h = φw. Removing a square of side w leaves a rectangle with dimensions (φw - w) × w = w(φ - 1) × w. Since 1/φ = φ - 1, this new rectangle has dimensions w × w/(φ) = w × w(φ-1) = w(φ-1) × w. The ratio is w/(w(φ-1)) = 1/(φ-1) = φ, proving it's also a golden rectangle. This process can continue infinitely, generating the golden spiral.
common_misconceptions: The Parthenon is a golden rectangle—DEBATED: Measurements vary, evidence is weak
Credit cards are golden rectangles—FALSE: Standard card ratio is 1.586, not 1.618
Golden rectangles are more aesthetically pleasing—MIXED: Studies show slight preference but not universal
All nature's rectangles are golden—FALSE: Many ratios appear in nature

construction_methods.formula: For any width w, set height h = φw where φ = (1+√5)/2

properties: Adding a square to the short side creates a larger golden rectangle
Removing a square from the long side creates a smaller golden rectangle
Diagonals of successive golden rectangles intersect at 'eye' of golden spiral
Area of nth rectangle in sequence = φⁿ⁻¹ × (area of first rectangle)
Perimeter ratio of successive rectangles = φ

golden_spiral_generation.method: Connect opposite corners of successive squares with quarter-circle arcs
golden_spiral_generation.mathematical_form: Logarithmic spiral with growth factor φ per quarter turn
